name: MS Paint Clone
description: A simple browser-based pixel art editor. This was a fun project to explore canvas manipulation and implementing features like a color palette and save/load functionality. I also worked with a friend to add multiperson canvases, allowing users to draw on the same canvas together, as well as place stickers of images at custom scales. This was my first website, and I learned by following a random guide to make the basics, and then looking up how to add the features that I wanted, such as more professional styling, images, and the multiperson drawing functionality.

name: Game Day Grill
description:
This project represents a significant milestone in my development journey. As the frontend developer on a three-person team for the Business Professionals of America (BPA) competition, I was tasked with bringing our application to life.

I began by building the interface in React, and the resulting application carried our team to a first-place win at the regional competition. After this success, I was eager to expand my skills. I had been researching other frameworks and was drawn to the elegance of Vue.js. I decided to challenge myself by completely rebuilding the frontend in Vue, and I immediately appreciated its efficient and enjoyable workflow.

The state competition taught me an invaluable lesson about how different factors, from backend readiness to judging criteria, can influence a project's outcome. While we didn't advance, the experience was fundamental to my growth. It solidified my confidence in not one, but two modern frameworks and stands as the first major website I built entirely with my own code.

name: Minecraft Coding Server -- Codename EmeraldICE
descrition: I worked with a friend to create a minecraft server in which you could program on the server using a JavaScript like code browser to interact with players in your personal world area.
